prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. What is the greatest number of Sundays that can occur in the first $49$ days of a year?
solution: 49 days is seven full weeks, so there are always $\boxed{7}$ Sundays.
gpt_response:
To determine the greatest number of Sundays that can occur in the first $49$ days of a year, we must first note that each week consists of $7$ days, and therefore every $7$-day period will contain exactly one Sunday.

Given that $49$ is a multiple of $7$, we know that there are $7$ full weeks in the first $49$ days of the year. In this case, each week will contain exactly one Sunday. Therefore, the greatest number of Sundays that can occur in the first $49$ days of a year is $\boxed{7}$.

Given that $49$ is a multiple of $7$, we know that there are $7$ full weeks in the first $49$ days of the year. In this case, each week will contain exactly one Sunday. Therefore, the greatest number of Sundays that can occur in the first $49$ days of a year is $\boxed{7}$.
